articles.title: The Bashtova Castle opens after restoration by EU4Culture, Gonzato: We honor the rich heritage of Albania
articles.summary: The inauguration ceremony of the Bashtova Castle gathered local authorities, representatives of the Diplomatic Corps in Albania, citizens, and tourists as an opportunity to emphasize the importance of sustainable tourism and the management of cultural heritage.
articles.content:
The inauguration ceremony of the Bashtova Castle gathered local authorities, representatives of the Diplomatic Corps in Albania, citizens, and tourists as an opportunity to emphasize the importance of sustainable tourism and the management of cultural heritage.

The Bashtova Castle, one of the jewels of Albania’s cultural heritage, has been restored and brought back to life with the support of the EU through EU4Culture. The 16th-century castle is now a vibrant space for culture, tourism, and community development.

The inauguration ceremony of the Bashtova Castle gathered local authorities, representatives of the Diplomatic Corps in Albania, citizens, and tourists as an opportunity to emphasize the importance of sustainable tourism and cultural heritage management.

“With the restoration of the castle, we want to honor Albania’s rich cultural heritage, but also to create opportunities for sustainable tourism,” said the EU ambassador to Albania, Silvio Gonzato.

“Through the EU4Culture program, we are not only restoring buildings but also creating opportunities for artists, craftsmen, and community engagement,” Gonzato continued.

The opening day of the Bashtova Castle was envisioned with plenty of activities and concerts enriching the life of the area.

“We want to create spaces for discussion, for connection, and for being open. It’s fantastic that a castle built for defense and isolation is turning into a space for engagement, for meetings, and for cultural discoveries. We need fewer walls and more spaces like this for our communities,” said Ambassador Gonzato.

Built in the 15th century, this castle represents a strategic point connecting Albania with the Mediterranean.

Albanian Minister of Economy, Culture, and Innovation Blendi Gonxhja stated that the Bashtova Castle has not only returned to its historical identity but has also been equipped with a modern visitor center, which offers information, contemporary services, and conditions for cultural, educational, and tourist activities.

“International examples show us that revitalizing heritage is an investment with multiple benefits: the castles of Dalmatia in Croatia, those of Puglia in Italy, or neighboring Greece have transformed into attractions visited every year by millions of tourists. Albania should also be part of this map, creating an itinerary of Albanian castles as one of the most beautiful cultural routes in the Balkans,” said Gonxhja.

The Bashtova Castle, with its space of thousands of square meters, is destined to become a multifunctional center: concerts, festivals, exhibitions, theatrical performances, educational activities for children and youth, as well as international thematic events will be held.

“This moment is an excellent example of cooperation between Albania and the European Union, a model that should inspire other similar projects,” said Gonxhja. (August 30)

This event has a positive real-world impact by preserving cultural heritage, promoting sustainable tourism, and fostering community engagement. The scope is significant as it involves cultural, educational, and economic benefits for the broader public and aims to integrate Albania into a wider regional cultural tourism network. **What happened** – On August 30, Bashtova Castle officially reopened after restoration. The ceremony included local leaders, diplomats, citizens, and tourists. The castle now features a modern visitor center and is ready to host cultural events like concerts, festivals, and exhibitions. The restoration was led by the EU4Culture program and Albanian authorities.

**Impact** – The castle’s restoration preserves an important piece of Albania’s history while creating new opportunities for tourism and community activities. It transforms a once isolated defensive structure into an open space for culture and learning. This project also connects Albania to other European countries with similar heritage tourism, helping to attract more visitors and support local artists and craftsmen.

Officials hope this success will encourage more projects that protect cultural heritage and boost sustainable tourism across Albania and the Balkans.

articles.title: First week 'critical' to avoid children missing school later, parents told
articles.summary: Data suggests more than half of children who miss a day at the start of term become persistently absent.
articles.content:
First week 'critical' to avoid children missing school later, parents told

5 hours ago Share Save Hazel Shearing Education correspondent Share Save

Getty Images

Pupils in England who missed school during the first week back in September 2024 were more likely to miss large parts during the rest of the year, figures suggest. More than half (57%) of pupils who were partially absent in week one became "persistently absent" - missing at least 10% of school, according to government data first seen by the BBC. By contrast, of pupils who fully attended the first week, 14% became persistently absent. Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson said schools and parents should "double down" to get children in at the start of the 2025 term, which is this week for most English schools.

The Conservatives said Labour's Schools Bill had dismantled a system that had "driven up standards for decades". A head teachers' union said more support was needed "outside of the school gates" to boost attendance. Schools have always grappled with attendance issues, but they became much worse after the pandemic in 2020 and schools closed to most pupils during national lockdowns. Attendance has improved since, but it remains a bigger problem than before Covid. Overall, about 18% of pupils were persistently absent in the 2024-25 school year, down from a peak of 23% in 2021-22 but higher than the pre-Covid levels of about 11%. The Department for Education (DfE) said the data from the first week of the 2024-25 school year showed the start of term was "critical" for tackling persistent absence.

Karl Stewart, head teacher at Shaftesbury Junior School in Leicester, said his school's attendance rates were higher than average and but there was a "definite dip" in the two years after Covid. "I get why. Some of that wasn't necessarily parents not wanting to send them in. It was because either they had got Covid or other things, they were saying, 'We'll just keep them off now to be sure'," he said. The school has incentives like awards and class competitions to keep absence rates down, and Mr Stewart said attendance had more or less returned to pre-Covid levels. "When we have the children in every day the results are just better," he said. "If you're here, that gives you more time for your teacher to notice you, for us to see all that good behaviour [and] that really hard work - and that's what we want." But, like lots of schools, he said some parents still took their children on unauthorised term-time holidays to make the most of cheaper costs. Others, he said, have taken children for medical treatments overseas to avoid NHS waiting lists.

Head teacher Karl Stewart says results are "just better" for pupils with high attendance

The education secretary said that while attendance improved last year, absence levels "remain critically high, putting at risk the life chances of a whole generation of young people". "Every day of school missed is a day stolen from a child's future," Phillipson said. "As the new term kicks off, we need schools and parents to double down on the energy, the drive and the relentlessness that's already boosted the life chances of millions of children, to do the same for millions more."

The DfE said 800 schools were set to be supported by regional school improvement teams - through attendance and behaviour hubs. These hubs are made up of 90 exemplary schools which will offer support to improve struggling schools through training sessions, events and open days. It said it had appointed the first 21 schools that will lead the programme. However, Pepe Di'Iasio, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said attendance hubs were not a "silver bullet" and a more "strategic approach" was needed.

"I think the government has worked really hard to improve attendance and it continues to be a priority for them, but there's certainly more to do," he told the BBC. "So many of the challenges that [school leaders] are facing come from beyond the school gates - children suffering with high levels of anxiety, issues around mental health." He said school leaders wanted quicker access to support for those pupils and specialist staff in schools, but pupils also needed "great role models" in the community through youth clubs and volunteer groups. Shadow education secretary Laura Trott said: "Behaviour and attendance are two of the biggest challenges facing schools and it's about time the government acted." She added: "There must be clear consequences for poor behaviour not just to protect the pupils trying to learn, but to recognise when mainstream education isn't the right setting for those causing disruption."
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the critical importance of school attendance in the first week of term to reduce persistent absenteeism, which has broad implications for children's education and future opportunities. It discusses ongoing efforts by schools and the government to improve attendance through support programs and community involvement, addressing a significant societal issue with detailed context and potential positive impact on youth development.
articles.personality_title: Missing school the first week raises risk of long-term absence, data shows
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In England, school attendance has been a challenge since the Covid-19 pandemic. While attendance rates have improved recently, many children still miss too much school. Missing school early in the term may lead to more days missed later.

**What happened** – New government data shows that more than half of the pupils who missed part of the first week of school in September 2024 became persistently absent, meaning they missed at least 10% of the school year. In contrast, only 14% of pupils who attended every day in the first week became persistently absent. Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson urged parents and schools to focus on getting children to school from day one of the 2025 term.

**Impact** – This data reveals how important the start of the school year is for preventing long-term absence. Missing school early can set a pattern that affects a child’s learning and future chances. Schools that keep attendance high report better results because teachers can support students consistently. However, challenges remain, such as parents taking children on holidays during term time or for medical treatments abroad.

**What’s next step** – The government plans to support 800 schools through special attendance and behaviour hubs. These hubs are made up of successful schools that will help others improve attendance with training and advice. Experts say more help is needed outside school, like mental health support and community programs, to tackle the reasons why children miss school.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Getting children to school from the first week is key to stopping long-term absences and helping students succeed.
articles.personality_title_fr: Manquer l'école la première semaine augmente le risque d'absences prolongées, selon les données
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En Angleterre, la fréquentation scolaire est un défi depuis la pandémie de Covid-19. Même si elle s'est améliorée récemment, de nombreux enfants manquent encore trop l'école. Manquer l'école au début de l'année peut entraîner davantage d'absences plus tard.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – De nouvelles données gouvernementales montrent que plus de la moitié des élèves qui ont manqué une partie de la première semaine de l'école en septembre 2024 sont devenus absents de façon persistante, c’est-à-dire qu’ils ont manqué au moins 10 % de l’année scolaire. En comparaison, seulement 14 % des élèves présents tous les jours la première semaine sont devenus absents persistants. La secrétaire à l’Éducation, Bridget Phillipson, a demandé aux parents et aux écoles de faire un effort pour que les enfants assistent à l’école dès le premier jour de la rentrée 2025.

**Impact** – Ces données montrent combien le début de l'année scolaire est important pour éviter les absences prolongées. Manquer l'école au début peut créer une habitude qui nuit à l’apprentissage et aux chances futures de l’enfant. Les écoles avec une bonne présence scolaire obtiennent de meilleurs résultats car les enseignants peuvent aider les élèves régulièrement. Cependant, certains problèmes restent, comme les vacances prises pendant les cours ou les soins médicaux à l'étranger.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement prévoit d’aider 800 écoles grâce à des centres d’amélioration de la présence et du comportement. Ces centres regroupent des écoles performantes qui aideront d’autres écoles à mieux gérer la présence avec des formations et des conseils. Des experts soulignent aussi la nécessité d’un soutien en dehors de l’école, comme l’aide à la santé mentale et des programmes communautaires, pour comprendre pourquoi certains enfants manquent l’école.

**En une phrase** – Assurer la présence des enfants dès la première semaine est essentiel pour éviter les absences longues et favoriser leur réussite.
articles.personality_title_es: Faltar a la escuela la primera semana aumenta el riesgo de ausencias prolongadas, según datos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Inglaterra, la asistencia a la escuela ha sido un problema desde la pandemia de Covid-19. Aunque ha mejorado, muchos niños siguen faltando demasiado. Faltar a la escuela al inicio del curso puede provocar más ausencias después.

**Qué pasó** – Nuevos datos del gobierno muestran que más de la mitad de los alumnos que faltaron parte de la primera semana de escuela en septiembre de 2024 se volvieron ausentes persistentes, es decir, faltaron al menos al 10 % del año escolar. En cambio, solo el 14 % de los alumnos que asistieron todos los días la primera semana se volvieron ausentes persistentes. La secretaria de Educación, Bridget Phillipson, pidió a padres y escuelas que se esfuercen para que los niños asistan desde el primer día del curso 2025.

**Impacto** – Estos datos muestran lo importante que es el comienzo del curso para evitar ausencias prolongadas. Faltar al inicio puede crear un patrón que afecta el aprendizaje y las oportunidades futuras. Las escuelas con buena asistencia tienen mejores resultados porque los profesores pueden apoyar a los alumnos de forma constante. Sin embargo, hay desafíos como las vacaciones en días lectivos o tratamientos médicos en el extranjero.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno planea apoyar a 800 escuelas mediante centros de mejora de asistencia y comportamiento. Estos centros están formados por escuelas exitosas que ayudarán a otras con formación y consejos. Expertos dicen que también se necesita más apoyo fuera de la escuela, como ayuda en salud mental y programas comunitarios, para entender por qué faltan algunos niños.

**Resumen en una frase** – Conseguir que los niños asistan desde la primera semana es clave para evitar ausencias prolongadas y ayudarles a tener éxito.
